In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Certainly! Below is a Julia function named `wrap_string` that takes a string and wraps it so that each line does not exceed the given `text_width`. By default, the `text_width` is set to 10 characters.

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    current_line_length = 0
    wrapped_text = ""

    for word in words
        word_length = length(word)
        # Check if adding the next word would exceed the line width
        if current_line_length + word_length > text_width
            wrapped_text *= "\n"  # Start a new line
            wrapped_text *= word  # Add the word to the new line
            current_line_length = word_length + 1  # +1 for the space
        else
            # If this is not the first word of the line, prepend a space
            if current_line_length > 0 
                wrapped_text *= " "
                current_line_length += 1  # Account for the space
            end
            wrapped_text *= word
            current_line_length += word_length
        end
    end

    return wrapped_text
end

# Example usage of wrap_string
text = "This is an example sentence that we want to wrap after a certain length."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text, 10)
println(wrapped_text)
```

Please note that the function simply adds each word to a current line until the line reaches or exceeds `text_width` characters. Once this happens, it starts a new line with the next word. This function does not handle cases where a single word is longer than the `text_width`â€”it will put the word on a new line, which could exceed the specified width.

Here's an example output if we run the provided script:

```

length.
```

In the above example, every line is wrapped so that it doesn't exceed 10 characters if possible, taking into account the spaces between words.
